content.raw:
If we want to make a test for checking that the audio played at least, we could capture audio for some seconds using OpenAL. 
Then, we could check the number of samples captured.

Apparently, there's an example [here](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/9886668/openal-playback-captured-audio-data-c).
content.html:
If we want to make a test for checking that the audio played at least, we could capture audio for some seconds using OpenAL. Then, we could check the number of samples captured.

Apparently, there's an example here.

content.raw: This is an example for capturing audio from a microphone. We would have to capture audio from the playback device itself.

@nkoenig that test coverage metrics are really nice, probably close to the ones needed in the avionic industry.

I was thinking about how to unit test the sound, more correctly speaking, integration-test the sound, since a unit test will imply use a stub for the sounds system. This could be an option, just create an stub to replace audio library calls, which will allow to test if correct orders where sent to the sound system (while not actually checking if something sounds or not).

Real integration test with native audio could be a bit harder, especially thinking on portability issues and related to something else being played while test is running.

content.raw: OpenAL makes the calls to the sound system. I think we'd have to build OpenAL against our special stub for this to work.
content.html: OpenAL makes the calls to the sound system. I think we'd have to build OpenAL against our special stub for this to work.

content.raw: It is not exacly the idea. Unit testing is about not using any other system than the one under test. In the current case, we should fake the OpenAL calls used in the code.
content.html: It is not exacly the idea. Unit testing is about not using any other system than the one under test. In the current case, we should fake the OpenAL calls used in the code.

content.raw: Ahh, okay. So we could create a fake OpenAL, and then check to make sure that the OpenAL functions were called when a world is started that use audio. I'll start looking into this.
content.html: Ahh, okay. So we could create a fake OpenAL, and then check to make sure that the OpenAL functions were called when a world is started that use audio. I'll start looking into this.

content.raw: Don't want to stop the pull request more, so feel free to open a ticket an assign it to me, if you prefer to focus on other duties. It was long time since I should introduce stubs in our testing. Google is providing gmock library for this effect.
content.html: Don't want to stop the pull request more, so feel free to open a ticket an assign it to me, if you prefer to focus on other duties. It was long time since I should introduce stubs in our testing. Google is providing gmock library for this effect.

content.raw:
I get compilation errors if I attempt to build without `libopenal-dev` installed. If this is a mandatory dependency, it should fail during configure. Otherwise, we should put checks in the CMakeLists.txt to not compile things that depend on OpenAL.
~~~
gazebo/util/OpenAL.cc:21:19: fatal error: AL/al.h: No such file or directory
~~~

Also, compiling on my mac fails with a similar warning, although cmake found OpenAL. I'm working on a patch.
~~~
gazebo/util/OpenAL.cc:21:10: fatal error: 'AL/al.h' file not found
#include <AL/al.h>
         ^
~~~
content.html:
I get compilation errors if I attempt to build without libopenal-dev installed. If this is a mandatory dependency, it should fail during configure. Otherwise, we should put checks in the CMakeLists.txt to not compile things that depend on OpenAL.

gazebo/util/OpenAL.cc:21:19: fatal error: AL/al.h: No such file or directory

Also, compiling on my mac fails with a similar warning, although cmake found OpenAL. I'm working on a patch.

gazebo/util/OpenAL.cc:21:10: fatal error: 'AL/al.h' file not found
#include <AL/al.h>
         ^

/home/scpeters/osrf/gazebo3/gazebo/util/OpenAL.cc: In member function ‘bool gazebo::util::OpenALSink::SetPose(const gazebo::math::Pose&)’:
/home/scpeters/osrf/gazebo3/gazebo/util/OpenAL.cc:189:31: warning: narrowing conversion of ‘* rot.gazebo::math::Matrix3::operator[](0ul)’ from ‘double’ to ‘ALfloat {aka float}’ inside { } is ill-formed in C++11 [-Wnarrowing]
/home/scpeters/osrf/gazebo3/gazebo/util/OpenAL.cc:189:42: warning: narrowing conversion of ‘*(rot.gazebo::math::Matrix3::operator[](0ul) + 8u)’ from ‘double’ to ‘ALfloat {aka float}’ inside { } is ill-formed in C++11 [-Wnarrowing]
/home/scpeters/osrf/gazebo3/gazebo/util/OpenAL.cc:189:53: warning: narrowing conversion of ‘*(rot.gazebo::math::Matrix3::operator[](0ul) + 16u)’ from ‘double’ to ‘ALfloat {aka float}’ inside { } is ill-formed in C++11 [-Wnarrowing]
/home/scpeters/osrf/gazebo3/gazebo/util/OpenAL.cc:190:31: warning: narrowing conversion of ‘* rot.gazebo::math::Matrix3::operator[](2ul)’ from ‘double’ to ‘ALfloat {aka float}’ inside { } is ill-formed in C++11 [-Wnarrowing]
/home/scpeters/osrf/gazebo3/gazebo/util/OpenAL.cc:190:42: warning: narrowing conversion of ‘*(rot.gazebo::math::Matrix3::operator[](2ul) + 8u)’ from ‘double’ to ‘ALfloat {aka float}’ inside { } is ill-formed in C++11 [-Wnarrowing]
/home/scpeters/osrf/gazebo3/gazebo/util/OpenAL.cc:190:53: warning: narrowing conversion of ‘*(rot.gazebo::math::Matrix3::operator[](2ul) + 16u)’ from ‘double’ to ‘ALfloat {aka float}’ inside { } is ill-formed in C++11 [-Wnarrowing]

The following fixes the warnings for me:

diff -r b007995ede06 gazebo/util/OpenAL.cc
--- a/gazebo/util/OpenAL.cc Tue Aug 20 14:48:02 2013 -0700
+++ b/gazebo/util/OpenAL.cc Tue Aug 20 15:05:02 2013 -0700
@@ -196,8 +196,12 @@

   // The first three values are the direction vector values.
   // The second three value are the up vector values.
-  ALfloat orient[] = {rot[0][0], rot[0][1], rot[0][2],
-                      rot[2][0], rot[2][1], rot[2][2]};
+  ALfloat orient[] = {static_cast<ALfloat>(rot[0][0]),
+                      static_cast<ALfloat>(rot[0][1]),
+                      static_cast<ALfloat>(rot[0][2]),
+                      static_cast<ALfloat>(rot[2][0]),
+                      static_cast<ALfloat>(rot[2][1]),
+                      static_cast<ALfloat>(rot[2][2])};

   // Clear error state
   alGetError();

content.raw:
The changes in 92397f6 and 627b4b7 broke the build for me. I have bullet installed; I'm guessing that you saw these warning because you don't have bullet installed?

I think [helper_physics_generator.hh](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/808b76d49b4309fd7c40c498599092f537cf3917/test/regression/helper_physics_generator.hh?at=default) is the guilty file. Perhaps `#define BULLET_SUPPORT(testclass)` should have a no-op instruction?
content.html:
The changes in 92397f6 and 627b4b7 broke the build for me. I have bullet installed; I'm guessing that you saw these warning because you don't have bullet installed?

I think helper_physics_generator.hh is the guilty file. Perhaps #define BULLET_SUPPORT(testclass) should have a no-op instruction?

content.raw: I ticketed the warnings when bullet is not installed as #807 in case you don't want to fix them now.
content.html: I ticketed the warnings when bullet is not installed as #807 in case you don't want to fix them now.

I get a seg-fault in osx without the following patch.

diff -r b3e8bc10b571 gazebo/common/AudioDecoder.cc
--- a/gazebo/common/AudioDecoder.cc Mon Aug 19 16:16:00 2013 -0700
+++ b/gazebo/common/AudioDecoder.cc Mon Aug 19 17:23:24 2013 -0700
@@ -57,13 +57,13 @@
 void AudioDecoder::Cleanup()
 {
 #ifdef HAVE_FFMPEG
+  // Close the codec
+  if (this->codecCtx)
+    avcodec_close(this->codecCtx);
+
   // Close the audio file
   if (this->formatCtx)
     avformat_close_input(&this->formatCtx);
-
-  // Close the codec
-  if (this->codecCtx)
-    avcodec_close(this->codecCtx);
 #endif
 }

content.raw: Done.
content.html: Done.

content.raw: Adding this line broke the build for me on quantal with openal installed. We need `#include "gazebo/gazebo_config.h"` before checking for `HAVE_OPENAL`.
content.html: Adding this line broke the build for me on quantal with openal installed. We need #include "gazebo/gazebo_config.h" before checking for HAVE_OPENAL.
